result.markdown:
--- title: "Visualization 1: kable()" author: "Maiko Hata" date: "2025-02-28" categories: [visualization, code, analysis] image: "kable.jpg" --- This is the first step in my visualization journey. I created a simple kable table using data from the Office of Special Education Programs ([OSEP](https://data.ed.gov/dataset/idea-section-618-data-products-static-tables-part-c)). To give some background, my dissertation will focus on equitable access to Early Intervention (EI) for different groups. Some of the visualizations in this blog will be adjusted to allow for stronger statistical analysis, such as by incorporating census data. Here’s what my dataset looked like after I finished wrangling the data: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} print(race_us_chart) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 7 × 7 Race Disqualified `Moved Out` `Not Determined` `Not Eligible` 1 Alaska Native or Ame… 3262 1045 2480 4395 2 Asian 6559 8031 22848 26712 3 Black or African Ame… 56155 14648 69687 65353 4 Hispanic or Latino 79951 26699 173416 165654 5 Two or More Races 11676 6477 15813 28996 6 Pacific Islander 977 559 1532 1911 7 White 99922 65399 178843 402568 # ℹ 2 more variables: `Part B Eligible` , Withdrawn ``` ::: ::: This may look like a simple visualization, but it took a lot of work to clean up the data to get here! I used many functions for data wrangling, including: `filter()`, `select()`, `mutate()`, `bind_rows()`, `mutate()`, `group_by()`, `pivot_longer()`, `pivot_wider()`, and `summarize()`. Just a few months ago, I was completely new to R, RStudio, and GitHub. # I WANT TO MAKE THE HEADER BOLD. Also the headers should be centered ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} kable(race_us_chart, caption = "Exit Reasons and Race (National)") %>% kable_styling( full_width = F, position = "left") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Exit Reasons and Race (National)
Race Disqualified Moved Out Not Determined Not Eligible Part B Eligible Withdrawn
Alaska Native or American Indian 3262 1045 2480 4395 9035 3155
Asian 6559 8031 22848 26712 52840 21737
Black or African American 56155 14648 69687 65353 139607 48699
Hispanic or Latino 79951 26699 173416 165654 318999 109469
Two or More Races 11676 6477 15813 28996 50699 19195
Pacific Islander 977 559 1532 1911 3587 1467
White 99922 65399 178843 402568 623690 242489
````` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} kable(race_us_chart, caption = "Exit Reasons and Race (National)", align = "c") %>% # Centers both headers and content kable_styling( full_width = F, position = "center", # Centers the entire table bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover")) %>% # Adds striped rows and hover effect row_spec(0, align = "c") # Centers header row ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Exit Reasons and Race (National)
Race Disqualified Moved Out Not Determined Not Eligible Part B Eligible Withdrawn
Alaska Native or American Indian 3262 1045 2480 4395 9035 3155
Asian 6559 8031 22848 26712 52840 21737
Black or African American 56155 14648 69687 65353 139607 48699
Hispanic or Latino 79951 26699 173416 165654 318999 109469
Two or More Races 11676 6477 15813 28996 50699 19195
Pacific Islander 977 559 1532 1911 3587 1467
White 99922 65399 178843 402568 623690 242489
````` ::: ::: I will build on this simple kable table to start analyzing the data more deeply. But first, I will show how disparities appear across the United States, where racially marginalized children are often underserved in Early Intervention, unlike in K-12 special education.
